snippet.textDisplay:
That UFO looks really cool. Such a device would also be great for travel. Not just a thing for "all in one people". Travel, vacation, mobile usage. It would only need a slight bit more battery life (3.5 hours maybe?) And it should be possible to charge it with a beefy USB Type C PD powerbank or a wall plug. It would be great of it used idk maybe less than 60 Watts or so so it can be charged on a plane or in a bus where the outlets aren't capable to supply a lot of power. Maybe fan noise could be an issue but I think that's fixable. Also some sort of protection during travel could be a good idea (like a face plate that clips to the front to protect the sticks and display). Expandable storage is important. Either an upgradeable M.2 SSD or an additional Micro SD slot would be awesome. Both would be the best. Pricing depends on the hardware. Multiple configurations would be good. Maybe ~$1k for the top model. It's not a full laptop and it probably doesn't feature the most powerful hardware so I think that's fair. Also you'll probably not be able to use it as your main computer. A docking station (not the switch style please) would be nice. But in this case another connector at the bottom would look cleaner than at the top. But please definitely keep the port at the top.
This is almost the exact same comment I posted under Hardware Canucks video but I really like this device and would love to give advice 😅
snippet.textOriginal:
That UFO looks really cool. Such a device would also be great for travel. Not just a thing for "all in one people". Travel, vacation, mobile usage. It would only need a slight bit more battery life (3.5 hours maybe?) And it should be possible to charge it with a beefy USB Type C PD powerbank or a wall plug. It would be great of it used idk maybe less than 60 Watts or so so it can be charged on a plane or in a bus where the outlets aren't capable to supply a lot of power. Maybe fan noise could be an issue but I think that's fixable. Also some sort of protection during travel could be a good idea (like a face plate that clips to the front to protect the sticks and display). Expandable storage is important. Either an upgradeable M.2 SSD or an additional Micro SD slot would be awesome. Both would be the best. Pricing depends on the hardware. Multiple configurations would be good. Maybe ~$1k for the top model. It's not a full laptop and it probably doesn't feature the most powerful hardware so I think that's fair. Also you'll probably not be able to use it as your main computer. A docking station (not the switch style please) would be nice. But in this case another connector at the bottom would look cleaner than at the top. But please definitely keep the port at the top. 
This is almost the exact same comment I posted under Hardware Canucks video but I really like this device and would love to give advice 😅

snippet.textDisplay:
When you connect the thing to a adapter to connect it to a larger screen, the module has a graphics card and you can select the type of graphics card on order. When you plug it in the bottom has a pci express port so the graphics card in the module connects to the on the go system. So when you want to play a quality pc game you just plug it in and then you have the power of the gpu that was in the module.

Express your comments and changes for this change.
snippet.textOriginal:
When you connect the thing to a adapter to connect it to a larger screen, the module has a graphics card and you can select the type of graphics card on order. When you plug it in the bottom has a pci express port so the graphics card in the module connects to the on the go system. So when you want to play a quality pc game you just plug it in and then you have the power of the gpu that was in the module.

Express your comments and changes for this change.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think maybe going 720p with a smaller screen size would be optimal (connected to an external display it could go higher). They could use some of the new Ryzen APUs and maybe aim for 60 fps+ with low Power consumption for longer battery life. I'm guessing they used NVMe SSD, but if not, that might be great for internal storage (maybe 500 GB default) and SD Card for extra storage.

Overall, I can see myself buying it with those specs and at least 16 GB RAM :D
snippet.textOriginal:
I think maybe going 720p with a smaller screen size would be optimal (connected to an external display it could go higher). They could use some of the new Ryzen APUs and maybe aim for 60 fps+ with low Power consumption for longer battery life. I'm guessing they used NVMe SSD, but if not, that might be great for internal storage (maybe 500 GB default) and SD Card for extra storage.

Overall, I can see myself buying it with those specs and at least 16 GB RAM :D

snippet.textDisplay:
I love the way they kind of put the word out on talking about the project:
"We've been studying a way to bring a new experience for gamers. As we couldn't come up with anything new, we've just blatantly copied some Google Stadia's ideas and we copied the Nintendo Switch".
snippet.textOriginal:
I love the way they kind of put the word out on talking about the project:
"We've been studying a way to bring a *new* experience for gamers. As we couldn't come up with anything new, we've just blatantly copied some Google Stadia's ideas and we copied the Nintendo Switch".

snippet.textDisplay: I agree with your statement about the Switch games being too expensive. I mean, if I buy a game that is on multiple platforms, I have to pay the same $60 for a "lower tier/quality" version. I stand by that I don't buy games for Switch unless they are $40 or under.

snippet.textDisplay: Dell should really focus on a good battery life and decent price point
snippet.textOriginal: Dell should really focus on a good battery life and decent price point

snippet.textDisplay:
Honestly if anyone from Dell is reading this, the Idea is great, really, I have been hoping for some sort of PC Portable gaming device to come out for a long time, I think with a 1080p screen you could set games to run at a lower res and it will still look amazing on this screen, plus most Indi games will run just perfect. (not to mention emulation)


But I think one of the most important things here is PRICE if Dell wants to have a HIT here they need to find the perfect balance between performance and Price, Dell always have expensive prices, but in this case I think if Dell honestly find a 399 price tag at most, they could have something truly revolutionary here that will honestly sell like hot cakes I will be there day 1.


More than that will be a hard pass from me.
snippet.textOriginal:
Honestly if anyone from Dell is reading this, the Idea is great, really, I have been hoping for some sort of PC Portable gaming device to come out for a long time, I think with a 1080p screen you could set games to run at a lower res and it will still look amazing on this screen, plus most Indi games will run just perfect. (not to mention emulation)


But I think one of the most important things here is PRICE if Dell wants to have a HIT here they need to find the perfect balance between performance and Price, Dell always have expensive prices, but in this case I think if Dell honestly find a 399 price tag at most, they could have something truly revolutionary here that will honestly sell like hot cakes I will be there day 1.


More than that will be a hard pass from me.

snippet.textDisplay:
That's all fine and good, but rather than building a PC that's sort of like a Switch, how about Nintendo just porting some of their first-party games to Steam? I like their software; I just don't want to buy another device. I ought to be able to play official Mario and Zelda games on my Alienware laptop.

I know there are emulators, but I want to be on the up and up.

snippet.textDisplay:
UFO looks amazing but slightly too big. Drop the size from 8 inch screen to 7 inch. Shrink it down a little for more comfortable handling, and drop the resolution to 800 or 960p. On a screen that small it would still look HD and free up a lot of processing power and battery life. That said, it must come with long braided charging cable for weekends at mother-in-law's or grandma's house.
We all have piles of unplayed AAA tiles waiting in our steam libraries thanks to steam sales.They need to bundle a matching Bluetooth keyboard and portable mouse. Make money on accessories. And for the love of all that is pure - Use a Ryzen 4000 chip. Intel chip - I'll go 800 USD. Ryzen 4000 - I'll go 1000 USD.
snippet.textOriginal:
UFO looks amazing but slightly too big.  Drop the size from 8 inch screen to 7 inch. Shrink it down a little for more comfortable handling, and drop the resolution to 800 or 960p. On a screen that small  it would still look HD and free up a lot of processing power and battery life. That said, it must come with long braided charging cable for weekends at mother-in-law's or grandma's house.
 We all have piles of unplayed AAA tiles waiting in our steam libraries thanks to steam sales.They need to bundle a matching Bluetooth keyboard and portable mouse. Make money on accessories. And for the love of all that is pure -  Use a Ryzen 4000 chip.  Intel chip - I'll go 800 USD. Ryzen 4000 - I'll go 1000 USD.
